bibl.title: Letter from Wickliffe Rose to Henry Rose Carter, July 5, 1918

div1.p: Rose informs Carter that the Rockefeller Foundation will continue to employ him for yellow fever work.

div1.head: Letter from Wickliffe Rose to Henry Rose Carter, July 5, 1918
div1.opener:

July 5, 1918.
Dear Dr. Carter:
div1.p:
Whenever we are making plans for yellow
fever work of any kind your name is the first one
to come up for consideration. Under similar cir-
cumstances we shall continue to call upon you in
future as we have done in the past. We know your
interest in the work and know also that we can
trust your judgment implicitly as to whether you
should go at any given time.

2. The work in Guatemala depends upon
the attitude of the President of that Republic.
Our Board has tendered to him its co-operation in
bringing the epidemic there under control. We
have communicated with him through his Minister in
Washington and through our own representative in
Guatemala. We should expect to hear from him at
2.
any time. So far no word has come.

3. If the President should desire our co-
operation, we hope to be able to secure the release
of Dr. White to go down to have charge of the work.
Dr. White thinks the outbreak could be brought under
control within about six weeks. If we should re-
ceive a favorable cable we shall undertake to move
rapidly.
div1.closer:
Very cordially yours, Wickliffe Rose. Dr. Henry R. Carter,
U. S. Marine Hospital Service,
Baltimore, Maryland.
